text:
the more I think of it, the more parallelisms I can find between vi vs emacs and python vs julia:

Python/vi:

* already available in many Unix systems (but often an old version)
* effective to get quick tasks done
* many people don't know how to quit it, even if they want to

Julia/Emacs:

* development started at MIT
* startup can be horribly slow
* powered by a more or less lisp-y language
* super extensible and composable
* many mind-blowing features/packages, hard to appreciate until you actually try them out

do you have anything to add?

text: I think this vi/emacs - python/julia parallelism, prompted by the thread above about tramp, should suggest us to not oversell julia.  emacs is venerable at this point of time, but it has lots of issues which users accept just because they believe they're good trade offs.  I personally don't seriously recommend Emacs to anyone, I don't think it's for everybody, it's for people who can enjoy it.  julia is no different
